name: soft
content:
soft

adjective
 
 
/sɒft/
 
/sɔːft/
(comparative softer, superlative softest)
Idioms
jump to other results

    not hard

  1.  
     changing shape easily when pressed; not stiff or hard
    • soft margarine
    • soft feather pillows
    • The grass was soft and springy.
    • They lay down on the soft sand.
    • These tomatoes have gone all soft.
    • The ground was soft and dry.
    • When the onion becomes soft, season with salt and pepper.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverbs
    • be
    • feel
    • look
    • …
    adverb
    • extremely
    • fairly
    • very
    • …
    See full entry
  2.  
     less hard than average
    • soft rocks such as limestone
    • soft corals
    • soft cheeses
    • the soft palate
    opposite hard
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverbs
    • be
    • feel
    • look
    • …
    adverb
    • extremely
    • fairly
    • very
    • …
    See full entry
    3.

    not rough

  3.  
     smooth and pleasant to touch
    • soft skin
    • a dress made from the finest, softest silk
    • The fabric has a beautifully soft texture.
    • Clean the lens with a soft cloth.
    opposite rough
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverbs
    • be
    • feel
    • look
    • …
    adverb
    • extremely
    • fairly
    • very
    • …
    See full entry
    4.

    without angles/edges

  4. not having sharp angles or hard edges
    • This season's fashions focus on warm tones and soft lines.
    • The moon's pale light cast soft shadows.
    5.

    light/colours

  5. [usually before noun] not too bright, in a way that is pleasant and relaxing to the eyes
    • a soft pink
    • the soft glow of candlelight
    opposite harsh
    Extra Examples
    • The paint needs to be thinned in order to obtain softer tones.
    • The roofs shone in the soft evening light.
    • Soft lighting is often used by restaurants to create atmosphere.
    Topics Colours and Shapesc1

    6. rain/wind

  6. not strong or violent synonym light
    • A soft breeze rustled the trees.
    7.

    sounds

  7. not loud, and usually pleasant and gentle synonym quiet
    • He chose some soft background music and lit the candles.
    • She had a soft voice and a kind face.
    8.

    kind

  8. kind and showing sympathy; easily affected by other people’s pain and problems
    • Julia's soft heart was touched by his grief.
    opposite hardTopics Personal qualitiesc2

    9. not strict

  9. (usually disapproving) not strict or severe; not strict or severe enough synonym lenient
    • soft (on somebody/something) The government is not becoming soft on crime.
    • soft (with somebody) If you're too soft with these kids they'll never respect you.
    • Critics say that this soft approach to truancy has failed.
    opposite tough

    10. crazy

  10. (informal) stupid or crazy
    • I must be going soft in the head.
    11.

    not brave/tough enough

  11. (informal, disapproving) not brave enough; wanting to be safe and comfortable
    • Stay in a hotel? Don't be so soft. I want to camp out under the stars.
    Topics Personal qualitiesc2

    12. too easy

  12. (disapproving) not involving much work; too easy and comfortable
    • They had got too used to the soft life at home.
    opposite hard

    13. water

  13. not containing mineral salts and therefore good for washing
    • You won't need much soap—the water here is very soft.
    opposite hard

    14. drink

  14. not alcoholic
    • soft beverages
    • ‘What would you like to drink?’ ‘Oh, something soft—I'm driving.’
    Topics Drinksc1

    15. consonants

  15. (phonetics) not sounding hard, for example ‘c’ in city and ‘g’ in general opposite hardTopics Languagec1
    16. Word OriginOld English sōfte ‘agreeable, calm, gentle’, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch zacht and German sanft.
Idioms
have a soft spot for somebody/something
(also Indian English have a soft corner for somebody/something)
  1. (informal) to like somebody/something
    • She's always had a soft spot for you.
    Topics Preferences and decisionsc2
See soft in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee soft in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: soft

name: soft key
content:
soft key

noun
 
/ˈsɒft kiː/
 
/ˈsɔːft kiː/
jump to other results
  1. a button on a a computer keyboard or mobile device which can be set to perform different functions
    • The soft keys have different functions, depending on the phone.
    • You can customize the functions of soft keys B and C.
